case_title: ASSOCIATED CEMENT COMPANIES LTD. vs PAKISTAN

accussed_details.name: Associated Cement Companies Ltd.
allegation: Illegal representation by Custodian of Enemy Property

complaint_summary: The appellant challenged income tax assessment orders issued by the respondents, claiming that the Custodian of Enemy Property improperly represented its interests and failed to appeal against the orders.
investigation_summary: The property of the appellant was vested in the Custodian of Enemy Property under notifications issued by the Government of West Pakistan. The Custodian admitted liability and paid taxes without filing appeals.
judgment_summary: The Supreme Court upheld the Lahore High Court's decision, dismissing the appeals on the grounds that the appellant, being an 'alien enemy,' lacked locus standi to pursue legal action in Pakistan. The Court ruled that the Custodian of Enemy Property had the authority to represent the appellant.
legal_arguments: Article 98 of the Constitution of 1962 does not confer substantive rights but provides remedies for aggrieved parties.
Section 83 of the Civil Procedure Code bars alien enemies from suing in Pakistani courts.
The Custodian of Enemy Property has extensive powers under the Enemy Property (Custody and Registration) Order, 1965.
Assessment orders were passed without jurisdiction and proper notice.
The Custodian acted beyond authority and failed to preserve the property.
assets: Pakistan Provident Fund of Associated Cement Companies Ltd.
sections: Section 22(3) and 29 of the Income Tax Act
Section 4 of the Defence of Pakistan Ordinance, 1965
citations: State Bank of India Ltd v. Custodian of Evacuee Property, West Pakistan (PLD 1969 Kar 1050)
Madhavan Nair Emperor v. Sibnath Banerjee (AIR 1945 PC 156)
key_issues: Locus standi of alien enemies in Pakistani courts
Authority of Custodian of Enemy Property
Validity of income tax assessment orders
Jurisdiction of the High Court under Article 98 of the Constitution of 1962
Applicability of Section 83 of the Civil Procedure Code, 1908

maxims.Alien Enemy Doctrine: Alien enemies are barred from suing in courts during hostilities.

legal_terms.Alien Enemy: A subject of a state at war with Pakistan or residing in enemy territory.
legal_terms.Custodian of Enemy Property: A government-appointed entity managing assets of alien enemies.

words_and_phrases.Locus Standi: The right to bring an action or appear in a court.
words_and_phrases.Enemy Territory: Territory under the sovereignty or administration of a state at war with Pakistan.

summary_vector_notes: The case involved the dismissal of appeals by Associated Cement Companies Ltd., an alien enemy, challenging income tax assessments. The Supreme Court upheld the Lahore High Court's decision, emphasizing the Custodian of Enemy Property's authority and the appellant's lack of locus standi.

custodian_appointment.role: Deputy Custodian under Rule 182 of the Defence of Pakistan Rules
Deputy Custodian for Provident Fund and other properties

custodian_appointment.authority: West Pakistan Enemy Property Management Board

issues: No notice served under Sections 22(3) and 29 of the Income Tax Act
Custodian admitted liability without proper representation

legal_findings.alien_enemy_status: The appellant was deemed an alien enemy under Section 83 of the Civil Procedure Code and related Defence of Pakistan Rules.
legal_findings.custodian_authority: The Custodian had extensive powers to manage, represent, and act on behalf of the appellant's properties.
legal_findings.jurisdiction: The High Court's jurisdiction under Article 98 did not override the bar on alien enemies filing suits.
legal_findings.assessment_orders: The Custodian's actions, including accepting tax liabilities, were within the scope of his authority.

conclusion.reasoning: The appellant, being an alien enemy, lacked the legal standing to challenge the orders. The Custodian acted within his powers under the Defence of Pakistan Rules and Enemy Property Order.
